content: Consumer credit reporting agency TransUnion (TRU) beat Q1 forecasts, raised its full-year guidance above consensus, and agreed to buy U.K.-based Callcredit.Estimates: Wall Street expects EPS to rise 21.1% to 46 cents per share according to Zacks Investment Research. Revenue is seen growing 11.4% to $507 million.Results: EPS of 57 cents on revenue of $537 million. U.S. online data services revenue rose 25% to $228 million, marketing services revenue grew 23% to $52 million, and decision services revenue climbed 8% to $63 million. International revenue rose 15% to $96 million, and consumer interactive revenue added 12% to $118 million.Outlook: Q2 EPS of 59-60 cents, vs. consensus views for 59 cents, on revenue of $534 million-$539 million, above views for $525 million. Full-year EPS is now seen at $2.37-$2.41, above views for $2.34, on revenue of $2.170 billion-$2.185 billion, above views for $2.14 billion."This was driven by strong performance in each of our segments, highlighted by the ongoing success of our innovation pipeline, attractive vertical markets and outstanding international positions," said CEO Jim Peck in a statement. "As we look ahead, we are well positioned to continue to deliver strong results in 2018 and beyond."Stock: TransUnion skyrocketed 10.4% to close at a record high of 66.84 on the stock market today, blasting above a 61.52 buy point from  a third-stage flat base. The breakaway gap is an unusually bullish move and establishes a new buy range with 64.03 as the entry.The company's relative strength line is also at an all-time high, and it boasts an unsurpassable IBD Composite Rating of 99, placing it in the top 1% of stocks tracked.Shares of Equifax (EFX) edged up 1.1% Friday.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseTransUnion is the smallest of the big three credit agencies, behind U.K.-listed Experian and Equifax. The firm also markets credit reports and other credit and fraud-protection products to consumers.YOU WILL ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Equifax Exec Charged By SEC For Dumping Stock After Learning Of Mass Data Breach Still Bullish On Bitcoin? A former Equifax (EFX) executive has been charged by the Securities and Exchange Commission for allegedly dumping his stock after learning of the company's massive data breach.X Jun Ying, who was the chief information officer, is facing insider trading charges for selling shares before the consumer credit reporting agency announced the cybersecurity failure last summer, which affected 147.9 million Americans.Ying exercised all of his vested Equifax stock, then sold the shares, reaping proceeds of nearly $1 million. He was able to avoid $117,000 in losses due to the illegal trades, according to the SEC.The U.S. Attorney's Office has also announced parallel criminal charges against Ying."As alleged in our complaint, Ying used confidential information to conclude that his company had suffered a massive data breach, and he dumped his stock before the news went public," Richard R. Best, director of the SEC's Atlanta regional office, said in a press release. "Corporate insiders who learn inside information, including information about material cyber intrusions, cannot betray shareholders for their own financial benefit."The SEC's complaint charges Ying with violating the antifraud provisions of federal securities laws and seeks disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus interest, penalties, and injunctive relief.Equifax stock closed down 0.4% at 123.19 on the stock market today. TransUnion (TRU) edged up 0.1% to 58.35.IBD'S TAKE: Despite the outrage against the company now, a JPMorgan analyst said Equifax will probably be fine. Equifax, which was founded in 1899, collects information on more than 800 million individual consumers and more than 88 million businesses worldwide.The Atlanta firm is one "Big Three" credit agencies along with Experian and TransUnion.Three other Equifax executives had previously drawn attention for disclosing stock sales just days before the breach was made public.CFO John Gamble sold almost $950,000 worth of shares, and U.S. information solutions president, Joseph Loughran, sold shares worth about $685,000 on Aug. 1. Workforce solutions president, Rodolfo Ploder, sold stock worth more than $250,000 on Aug. 2. However, Equifax found that none of those executives knew about the breach when they sold their securities.The big breach began in mid-May, but was not observed until July 29, according to Equifax. But the company waited until Sept. 7 to publicly disclose the hack.As well as the American customers, information on up to 44 million British residents as well as 8,000 Canadian residents were also compromised. It is one of the biggest data breaches in history.There was also a breach in March 2017, which was reported on Sept. 18, 2017. According to Bloomberg, a person familiar with the breach said this intrusion may have been carried out by the same hackers who breached the company's systems in May.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Still Bullish On Bitcoin? Read The Cautionary Tale Of This Blockchain StockEquifax CEO Richard Smith Retires After Mass HackBanks And Financial Stock NewsStocks To Buy And Watch: Top IPOs, Big And Small Caps, Growth Stocks

MFS Mid Cap Growth Fund (OTCIX) is flexing its muscles. After topping 69% of its midcap growth rivals tracked by Morningstar.com last year with a 26.29% return, the $3.1 billion portfolio is outpacing 86% of its peers with a 15.33% gain this year going into June 21.It's also topping the S&P 500's modest 4.46% advance. The fund's strong performance this year has been fueled by holdings that include such leading growth stocks as Abiomed (ABMD), Netflix (NFLX), Lululemon Athletica (LULU), TransUnion (TRU) and Five Below (FIVE).Gains this year by those stocks range from 30% by TransUnion to 104% by Netflix and 118% by Abiomed.Relative performance has ramped up for this growth fund this year as many holdings have posted solid financial results. "The first quarter was particularly strong for us with many stocks reporting good earnings and an unusually low number of misses (in comparison to analysts' forecasts)," co-manager Paul Gordon said.Solid stock picking has been another factor. The market tide is no longer rising, lifting all boats. "Volatility in markets has picked up and correlations have dropped," Gordon said. "There is more separation between winners and losers."Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseAmid tighter monetary conditions, investors have gravitated mainly into stocks posting the most attractive earnings gains, he adds.In addition, Gordon and his colleagues Eric Fischman and Matthew Sabel aim to control risk. "We construct the portfolio so no single sector, industry or security will be more than 500 or 600 basis points over or under our benchmark, the Russell Midcap Growth Index," Gordon said.The growth fund began its current stake in Abiomed in Q1. "(It's) key driver is a heart pump called Impella, which is focused on an unserved part of the heart disease market," Gordon said. "It has been extremely successful because it improves patient outcomes — fewer deaths, fewer re-hospitalizations — and lowers cost to the system."Abiomed is only 10% penetrated in what they call their total addressable market, Gordon says. "But that TAM could increase as they expand into other indications in the future," he added.Netflix's earnings per shares grew at a triple-digit pace in four of the past six quarters. "With 125 million paying subscriber base, there's a significant long-term runway for that number to go higher, based on the number of people in the world paying for TV and connected to the internet," Gordon said.Also, Netflix share price — which set all-time highs above 400 in June — got a boost when the company demonstrated pricing power in a series of price hikes. "What the market really liked was that there was no significant change in the number of people who unplugged because of price increases," Gordon said.IBD'S TAKE: Keep your eye on Netflix by checking in to IBD's online page devoted to news and analysis focused on the content provider.Athletic apparel maker Lululemon's quarterly EPS growth has accelerated, growing 3%, 19%, 33% and 72% the past four stanzas. Share price is up more than 60% so far this year. Are there that many people taking up yoga? Or is the stock's jump due to an increasing number of people who want to wear stylist exercise garb even when they are nowhere near a yoga studio? Or is it a combination of the two?The stock's uptrend is a recovery from the slide that occurred from mid-2016 to mid-2017. Gordon attributes it to getting past quality and assortment problems that weighed on company performance."After several years of operational issues that distracted the company, they've come out strong on the innovation side, both in women's and men's apparel," Gordon said.The growth fund began to buy TransUnion in November after deciding to exit Equifax (EFX) in the wake of its data breach scandal. "We think there is a need for their (credit reporting) product," Gordon said. "We think the Equifax issues were isolated and that it's possible TransUnion could gain market share as a result."The MFS team likes TransUnion in its own right. "We believe TransUnion could have above-industry growth from innovation in its core credit (business) that will make credit decisions more accurate and thereby drive pricing," Gordon said.He also says the company should benefit from further penetration into the health care, auto and insurance markets, and from greater exposure to emerging markets.Five Below's price discounts and focus on a teen market help insulate it from the problems dogging many brick-and-mortar retailers. "They are more isolated from the Amazon (AMZN) threat," Gordon said. "Like other dollar-store or off-price concepts, they offer a treasure hunt to their younger skewed demographic. It also has one of the longest runways for store growth in all of retail."The chain now operates more than 400 stores, "and long-term they believe they could operate over 2,000," Gordon said. "It will take longer than five years at their current rate of growth."The chain benefited last year from strong sales of Fidget Spinners. Five Below posted strong comparable sales in its latest quarter, surprising investors who expected a letdown after the Fidget Spinner fad. "This showed that the company can comp impressively without the benefit of a hot trend," Gordon said.Get instant access to more trading ideas, exclusive stock lists and IBD proprietary ratings for only $5.YOU MAY ALSO LIKE:You Need This Much Retirement Savings At Your Age And IncomeMillennials: Tips For Reaching Goal Of Becoming A Millionaire

The WannaCry cybersecurity attack in May, 2017, targeted tens of thousands of computers scattered across more than 70 countries. The attackers, thought to a be a group located in North Korea, demanded ransom fees in bitcoin. They promised to unfreeze computers in return. The assault on global network computing underscored the internet's rampant vulnerabilities. It caused Britain's public health system…

After being dominated by small-cap stock funds the year before, the best large-cap mutual funds came back strong in the third annual IBD Best Mutual Funds 2018 Awards.Winning Best Mutual Funds Awards isn't easy. The best large-cap mutual funds don't just beat their index for one year. The same goes for the best midcap mutual funds and the best small-cap mutual funds. They need to beat the S&P 500 Index in the one-, three-, five-, and 10-year periods.IBD looked at funds at least 10 years old with at least $100 million in assets. Out of 661 large-cap mutual funds meeting those criteria, 92 beat the S&P 500 in all four periods. Of 231 midcap mutual funds, only 16 qualified. And out of 295 small-cap funds, just 17 took top honors.Large-cap mutual funds hold stocks with large market capitalization, which is derived by multiplying number of shares outstanding by the share price. Morningstar Inc. defines large caps as stocks in the top 70% the capitalization of U.S. stocky market. This means a market cap greater than $20 billion.Of the five best large-cap mutual funds capturing IBD awards in 2018, four are index funds. The only actively managed award winning fund is $5.3 billion Fidelity OTC (FOCPX), which took top place in the first Mutual Fund Awards. After a manager shake-up in September 2017, Sonu Kalra who ran the fund from 2005 to 2009, returned to co-run it.OTC is an aggressive growth stock fund that seeks capital appreciation. Kalra looks for companies with a strong franchise, a high bar that other companies must clear in order to compete, and strong management team aligned with shareholders.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of Use"Larger companies are doing better because the global economy is doing better," said Kalra. "If you look at the indicators over the past several months, they indicate the global economy will continue on that path."The fund holds many of the top tech stocks like Apple (AAPL), Alphabet (GOOG), the parent of Google, Amazon.com (AMZN), Facebook (FB), Tesla (TSLA), and Nvidia (NVDA).Kalra also likes video game maker Activision Blizzard (ATVI). He said there many revenue opportunities with game makers like Activision. With digital downloads, they get revenue immediately and don't share any with retail stores. Consumers also purchase upgrades while playing to enhance their chances of winning. In addition, they are moving the franchise onto smartphones and away from consoles to widen their audience. Video game makers are now building leagues where people watch players in stadiums. This brings in ticket sales, merchandise revenue, food and other revenue streams.Chip Reed the co-portfolio manager of the Eaton Vance Capital SMID-Cap Fund (EISMX) has been managing the fund since inception. He said the midcap range starts around $6 billion to $8 billion.He says he's more cautious on the economy these days and spends a lot of time looking, but not a lot of time buying.He likes credit rating agency TransUnion (TRU), which should benefit from the sell-off in Equifax (EFX). He said TransUnion upgraded its technology and has been aggressive about picking up market share.Fair Isaac (FICO), which takes the credit bureaus' data and makes your credit score, has been a home run for the fund.Markel (MKL) is a specialty insurance company that takes nonstandard, higher-risk policies that larger firms can't make money on. "They've figured out how to make money by underwriting these policies. It's one of our favorites," said Reed.Among the best small-cap mutual funds is Virtus KAR Small Cap Growth (PXSGX). Todd Beiley, co-portfolio manager, said he looks for three things when buying a business, durable competitive barriers, a compelling opportunity he can understand and a price that makes sense. He doesn't find many. The fund only owns 28 stocks and most of them it's owned more than five years."We try to find great businesses and sit on our hands as much as possible," said Beiley. It seems to be working. Last year the fund returned 37%. It also beat its benchmark, the Russell 2000 Growth Index, in all time periods, as well.Among Beiley's top picks is the Rightmove ADR.  This firm is the U.K.'s leading online listings website for residential properties. He said it's a very profitable company because it doesn't require a lot of capital to operate, it has about 80% market share, which gives it pricing power, and operating margins are greater than 70%. It also distributes excess cash flow back to shareholders as dividends and share buybacks.Fox Factory Holding (FOXF), a maker of high-performance suspension products for mountain bikes, off-road trucks and all-terrain vehicles, has more than a 50% market share in a specific product category where brand and reputation are very important, Beiley says.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:Read The Full IBD Best Mutual Funds Awards 2018 Special ReportHere's The List Of The Best Mutual Funds Award Winners By CategoryBest Mutual Funds: News, Performance Reports And Investing IdeasHow To Invest Like Fidelity Stock Gurus Will Danoff And John RothWhich Stocks Are The Best Mutual Funds Buying — And Selling?

Four Equifax (EFX) executives did not commit insider trading when they sold shares of the credit-rating bureau in the days after it discovered a massive security breach, according to findings from a special committee that were released Friday.XThe committee, which was formed in September to investigate those trades, said that "none of the four executives had knowledge of the incident when their trades were made, that pre-clearance for the four trades was appropriately obtained, that each of the four trades at issue comported with Company policy, and that none of the four executives engaged in insider trading."The committee, composed of independent Equifax board members, found that CFO John Gamble, president of U.S. information relations Joseph Loughran, investor relations director Douglas Brandberg, and workforce solutions president Rodolfo Ploder first learned that "a security issue was being investigated" at various points in August after the sales occurred.The stock sales were the subject of a criminal investigation by the Justice Department, Bloomberg reported in September. The breach led to the departures of CEO Richard Smith and other executives.Suspicions of the trades were first raised after Equifax detailed the timing of the breach, which left more than 145 million U.S. consumers vulnerable to identity theft and left many feeling hopeless about their ability to protect their personal information.The company said that the data breach — in which hackers likely accessed Social Security and driver's license numbers, birth dates and addresses — likely occurred from mid-May through July, and that it discovered the intrusion on July 29.CFO John Gamble sold $946,374 worth of the company's stock on Aug. 1. Joseph Loughran also sold shares on that date. Ploder and Brandberg made their trades on Aug. 2. Equifax disclosed the breach to the public on Sept. 7.Equifax shares were down 0.2% at 108.70 on the stock market today and are more than 25% off their high reached before the hack was revealed.  Rival TransUnion (TRU) rose 0.8% to 53.86, a record close.IBD'S TAKE: Despite the outrage against the company now, a JPMorgan analyst said Equifax will probably be fine. Yum Brands' (YUM) Pizza Hut, Amazon's (AMZN) Whole Foods and Sonic (SONC) and Hyatt (H) are among the companies that have disclosed security breaches in recent weeks. According to an Ars Technica report last month, Equifax's site was being used to send out fake, malicious Flash updates.That news was "just Reason No. 10,000 why consumers should assume their personal information is already out there and act accordingly," Matt Schulz, a senior industry analyst from CreditCards.com, said in an emailed statement at that time.RELATED:Sonic Discloses That Hackers Breached Customers' Credit CardsEquifax CEO Richard Smith Retires After Mass HackKey Question On Equifax Options Trade Is Who Initiated OrderEquifax Stock Sales Said To Be Focus Of U.S. Criminal Probe

Equifax CEO and Chairman Richard Smith retired, effective immediately, in the wake of a massive hack recently disclosed that may have exposed up to 143 million Americans.The cybersecurity incident has affected millions of consumers, and I have been completely dedicated to making this right.  At this critical juncture, I believe it is in the best interests of the company to have new leadership to move the company forward," Smith said in a statement.The credit reporting agency named Equifax president of Asia-Pacific Paulino do Rego Barros as interim CEO and current director Mark Feidler as nonexecutive chairman. The company will search for a permanent CEO.Equifax shares fell 2.45% to 102.52 just before the opening bell on the stock market today. The stock has tumbled 26% since Sept. 7, when Equifax disclosed the hack and then came under heavy criticism over the time of the release and some of its subsequent steps. But shares have rebounded in recent sessions.RELATED:Key Question On Equifax Options Trade Is Who Initiated OrderEquifax Stock Sales Said To Be Focus Of U.S. Criminal ProbeEquifax Fallout Continues, But The Hack's Earnings Effect Will Surprise YouWhat You Should Do Now To Protect Yourself From The Equifax Data Breach

Getting to the bottom of an Equifax (EFX) options trade that has reportedly piqued the interest of congressional investigators will require a determination that plagues anyone looking for villains in markets.Namely, who made the trade. Not the person's name, necessarily, but whether he came to the market as a buyer or a seller. Getting an answer will be key to telling if the transaction is evidence of illicit intent, or just another weirdly timed options trade that doesn't amount to anything.And while it's impossible to be definitive, a couple traders see signs it was the latter.The question is of extra consequence in Equifax, where data show a surge in bearish put contracts weeks before the credit-reporting firm disclosed a security breach that sent its stock down 35%. CNBC reported Wednesday that a House committee is seeking information on the trades, which Business Insider said could've grossed $10 million.An Equifax spokeswoman didn't respond to a telephone call seeking comments on the options trades. The reported probe is separate from a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of stock sales by Equifax insiders before the Sept. 7 disclosure.One piece of data the panel will be interested in is whether volume in the options was initiated by buyers or sellers. While puts in their simplest form are wagers that a stock will fall, in the through-the-looking-glass world of derivatives markets, an equally important consideration is whether the trader was bullish or bearish when he entered the transaction.In short, someone who sold the put — that is, had a bearish view on the contract, as opposed to buying it — would not have made money in the subsequent Equifax rout. While "selling a put" sounds absurd — betting on a decline in an option that itself is a bet on a decline in a stock — it happens all the time. Traders do it when they're convinced a stock won't fall and want to pocket the price of the option.Establishing who makes and loses money on a given options trade is as much art as science. In the case of Equifax, data compiled by Bloomberg show that almost 2,700 puts changed hands on Aug. 21, the most for any day since 2005, including two blocks of 1,250 September $135 puts each. At the same time, some see evidence those contracts were "sold" — that is, a seller approached market makers and asked the options be "written" and purchased from him.What evidence? Mainly that the two blocks of options changed hands at 70 cents and 75 cents, or near the "bid," the market price set by a buyer (the options had a bid/offer spread of 70/95 cents). Normally, when a seller initiates a transaction, he must do it at his counterparty's terms."The size is definitely unusual given the average total daily volume below 50 contracts, but the trade details suggest an opening seller initiated the trade, so it's not quite the smoking gun that some other reports have suggested," Henry Schwartz, president of analytics firm Trade Alert wrote in an email. "Based on implied volatility and the bid-offer spread at the time of the trade, it seems very clear the options were sold given the $0.70 and $0.75 execution prices."A sold option could conceivably be part of a larger, bearish trade, such a short sale on the underlying stock, but there's little evidence that was the case here, said Peter Cecchini, chief market strategist at Cantor Fitzgerald."Based on the reading of the tape we don't see any indication there was a stock portion to this," Cecchini said. "It looks like it was a seller, and either way it didn't work out very well for whomever sold the put unless they closed it prior to the news, and doesn't look like that happened."

The U.S. Justice Department has opened a criminal investigation into whether top officials at Equifax (EFX) violated insider trading laws when they sold stock before the company disclosed that it had been hacked, according to people familiar with the investigation.Prosecutors are looking at the stock sales by Equifax Chief Financial Officer John Gamble; President of U.S. Information Solutions Joseph Loughran; and President of Workforce Solutions Rodolfo Ploder, said two people, who asked not to be named because the probe is confidential.The company and the executives didn't immediately respond to requests for comment.Equifax disclosed earlier this month that it discovered a security breach on July 29. The three executives sold shares worth almost $1.8 million in early August. The company has said the managers didn't know of the breach at the time they sold the shares.To run afoul of laws that prohibit insider trading, a seller has to be aware of nonpublic information, said Stephen Crimmins, a former enforcement lawyer for the Securities and Exchange Commission.The probe will be handled by the U.S. attorney's office in Atlanta, where the credit firm's headquarters is located, said one of the people.  A spokesman for the U.S. attorney's office in Atlanta declined to comment.More than one third of U.S. senators have called on the Securities and Exchange Commission, in addition to the Justice Department, to get to the bottom of whether Equifax managers violated insider trading laws when they sold stock days after the company found out it was hacked.Separately, state and federal regulators and law enforcers are scrutinizing the company's data security practices and its response to the breach. The U.S. Federal Trade Commission and a Congressional committee with subpoena power last week joined the growing number of bodies scrutinizing the cyber attack that may have compromised the privacy of 143 million U.S. consumers.

Heat continues to mount on credit reporting agency Equifax (EFX), which last week disclosed a massive breach in which hackers stole the personal identification information of as many as 143 million consumers.XOn Thursday, an open-source software organization said that it had publicly posted a patch for the vulnerability that hackers used to access Equifax data about two months before the hack, but that apparently Equifax did not install the patch before the breach took place, if it ever did.Separately on Thursday, the Federal Trade Commission said it is investigating the data breach. In addition, several congressional bills were filed that would hold Equifax and other data brokers accountable for such errors. And on Friday, U.S. Sen. Elizabeth Warren said she and other senators will introduce a bill to require credit bureaus to let consumers freeze their credit for free, according to Reuters news service. Some credit agencies charge around $5.A credit freeze blocks criminals from setting up bogus accounts whose purchases get charged to victims.The open-source software organization, the Apache Software Foundation (ASF), told IBD that it posted a patch for the vulnerability known as CVE-2017-5638 in the Apache Struts program on March 7.Equifax identified that as the vulnerability that hackers used. But the hack did not take place until mid-May through July, Equifax has said. Equifax realized it had been breached on July 29. Equifax disclosed the breach on Sept. 7.ASF suggested that an organization such as Equifax is presumed to be aware of such postings, but ASF does not know what if anything Equifax did know about the patch. It said that Equifax is not a customer of ASF and that ASF has no one-on-one relationship with Equifax.ASF spokeswoman Sally Khudairi told IBD by email: "The Apache Software Foundation provides Open Source software that is freely available to all at no cost or restriction on its use. Those who wish to use our software projects simply download the projects from apache.org and/or one of many globally-distributed mirror sites."Khudairi added: "Any risks, along with patches, are announced and widely shared with Apache project communities. In addition, security vulnerabilities or exploits are disseminated on sites such as NIST (U.S. Department of Commerce National Institute of Standards and Technology) as well as dozens (if not hundreds) of software providers and security specialists (such as MITRE and Symantec)."Further, Khudairi said, "As with all Apache software, patches are made available to the public at large. Financial services organizations are often known for being highly aware of security vulnerabilities in general, and are therefore particularly vigilant with their processes for patching any known exploits."Equifax has not yet responded to IBD questions concerning the patch.ASF oversees more than 350 leading open source projects, including Apache HTTP Server — which it calls the world's most popular web-server software. ASF is a not-for-profit charitable organization, whose sponsors include high-profile corporations such as Capital One (COF), Comcast (CMCSA), Facebook (FB), Google (GOOGL), IBM (IBM), Microsoft (MSFT), Red Hat (RHT), Target (TGT) and Yahoo.Any entity can use ASF's software, even if they are not a sponsor. Equifax is not a sponsor.No one using the "@equifax" domain has communicated via email with ASF for almost two years, Khudairi says. ASF can't tell if an Equifax person communicated with ASF using a personal email address.On Sept. 8, the day after disclosing the breach, Equifax stock gapped down 14%. In the stock market today, its shares were trading near 91.40, down 37% from its 52-week high reached July 26.Shares in Symantec (SYMC), which owns credit monitoring service LifeLock, broke out above a 33.32 buy point in an irregular base Tuesday. It dipped below the buy point the next two days but rose back above it Friday. The stock ranks fourth in IBD's computer software security group, according to IBD's Stock Checkup. The industry group's ranking has risen to 60 from 177 three weeks ago. IBD tracks 197 industry groups.RELATED:Should You Join Lawsuits Mushrooming Against Equifax?Bogus Online Transactions Are Up In Wake Of Equifax BreachWhat You Should Do Now To Protect Yourself From The Equifax Data Breach

In a season of disastrous hurricanes, beleaguered credit bureau Equifax (EFX) is in the volatile eye of a storm of angry consumers and investors. The credit reporting company has been hit by more than 30 lawsuits in the U.S., according to Reuters news service, including at least one suit accusing the company of securities fraud. And it appears to have backed off one maneuver that inflamed consumer ire.XThe suits stem from the massive theft of personal identification information from Equifax that the firm disclosed last week. The data breach took place from mid-May through July, Equifax said.Are you mad enough at Equifax to wonder how to start or join a lawsuit? Think you might feel that way if you discover that someone has bought, say, a new television and charged it to your name and address? And you begin to suspect the cyber crook got his information about you from Equifax?You can either start your own suit or join someone else who has already done so. If you do an online search for phrases like "Equifax lawsuit how to join," you'll find news reports of people and lawyers who've already taken action. After a few more search steps, you'll have lawyers' contact information and you can reach out.You can also ask your own lawyer to recommend an appropriate counsel.One thing you can bet on is that multiple lawsuits will be filed independently of each other. "The class action lawyer who represents the biggest damaged person or the biggest sheer number of victims will likely be appointed class counsel," said Chicago securities fraud lawyer Andrew Stoltmann. "Eventually all will be consolidated into one (case)."Once someone is appointed class counsel, that lawyer in discovery gets to ask Equifax for the names and contact information of the people whose data was stolen from the credit reporting service. That pilferage involved information for as many as 143 million U.S. consumers, the firm says.The class-action counsel can then contact those people and invite them to join the suit.A class-action lawsuit will likely take three to six years, Stoltmann says.IBD'S TAKE: For advice about how to protect yourself from being victimized by identity thieves, read this IBD report about how to take real-world, practical steps to safeguard yourself and your personal identification information.In the first days after Equifax disclosed the data hack, people on social-media sites accused Equifax of not only endangering the financial health and peace of mind of millions of Americans, but also of forcing them to waive their right to sue the company if they wanted to find out from Equifax if their data had been among the information stolen. Critics said that the waiver came about when people logged in to use two Equifax websites. To proceed, users had to agree to the sites' terms of use, which include the waiver and the site user's consent to submit to arbitration instead.In apparent response to social-media criticism, Equifax reportedly had said it did not plan to hold victims of the data breach to their waiver and arbitration agreement. But securities fraud attorney Andrew Stoltmann told IBD that Equifax would still be free to hold victims to the waiver. "It's my understanding that this is simply what they have said and the company isn't bound by it if they haven't taken the binding arbitration agreement out."Apparently in part to quell criticism, Equifax says it has deleted the waiver and arbitration agreement. Spokeswoman Meredith Giffanti told IBD via email, "To confirm (IBD's question), enrolling in the free credit file monitoring and identity theft protection products that we are offering as part of this cybersecurity incident does not prohibit consumers from taking legal action. We have already removed that language from the Terms of Use on the site www.equifaxsecurity2017.com. The Terms of Use on www.equifax.com do not apply to the TrustedID Premier product being offered to consumers as a result of the cybersecurity incident. Again, to be as clear as possible, we will not apply any arbitration clause or class action waiver against consumers for claims related to the free products offered in response to the cybersecurity incident or for claims related to the cybersecurity incident itself."Equifax and the other two major national credit reporting services may seek a silver lining in this attack by selling products and services to consumers who want to protect their personal data. Credit freezes, for one, are subject to fees, which can vary depending on your home state. Nick Sloane of Sloane Wealth Management said, "I anticipate (Equifax) will actually try to profit from this incident by selling upgraded stuff, like more frequent access to credit reports or extending the monitoring for a fee."Sloane adds that he does not believe that inquiring about the status of one's data with Equifax would expose a consumer to additional security risk. But, he adds, he's not sure any consumer should believe Equifax if it says your data was not hacked. "I don't think it is 'unsafe' to do so," he said. "My comment is ... I would not believe them either way (why should you; they took how long to inform the public?)."Even if your data wasn't already hacked, you should consider security steps like a credit freeze, Sloane adds. "If companies who have sensitive consumer information get their sites hacked (Target (TGT) comes to mind), then of course this will happen again. I really think it does not matter if you found out that you were or were not part of a data breach after it happened; it is likely going to occur to you and to me at some point."Equifax disclosed the data breach last week. The company indicated that it realized it had been hacked on July 29.The data theft involved files that included people's names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and in some cases driver's license numbers. "It poses an identity-theft threat to tens of millions of people," said Jocelyn Baird, associate editor of NextAdvisor, a consumer information website.Equifax shares sold off on Friday and Monday. They closed down nearly 21% on Monday from their Sept. 7 closing price. They rallied nearly 2% Tuesday.RELATED:Here's A Look At Cybersecurity Stocks That Rose After The Equifax HackHow Much Salary You Need To Buy A HomeYou Need This Much Retirement Savings At Your Age And Income

In the wake of the massive theft of personal identification information from Equifax (EFX), what can you do to protect yourself from cyber crooks?Fortunately, there are defensive steps you can take.Here are links to each bureau's freeze site: Equifax, Experian and TransUnion. Each bureau may charge you a fee, and those fees may vary depending on which state you live in.You may not be charged a fee if you can prove that you're a victim of identity theft.Here are additional steps you can take to protect yourself:The data theft from Equifax involved information for as many as 143 million U.S. consumers. That's nearly half the size of the population of the nation. The danger is that cyber hoods will use the data to make purchases or establish credit that get billed to victims — people like you, perhaps you yourself.Equifax disclosed the data breach last week. The company indicated that it realized it had been hacked back on July 29.The data theft involved files that included people's names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and in some cases driver's license numbers. "It poses an identity-theft threat to tens of millions of people," said Jocelyn Baird, associate editor of NextAdvisor, a consumer information website.In addition, the hackers had accessed credit card numbers of about 209,000 consumers, Equifax revealed. Equifax (EFX), one of the three major U.S. credit bureaus, says online thieves stole sensitive data for as many as 143 million U.S. consumers. The theft involved files that included people's names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and in some cases driver's license numbers. "It poses an identity-theft threat to tens of millions of people," said Jocelyn Baird, associate editor of NextAdvisor, a consumer information website.The hackers could misuse the information or sell it to criminals who then use it to make purchases that get billed to victims — people like you, perhaps you yourself — whose information was swiped from Equifax.So, what can you do to protect yourself? Baird recommends that you take these steps:In exchange, Equifax appeared initially to require people seeking that service to waive their right to participate in a class-action lawsuit against the Atlanta-based firm that was triggered by the cybertheft. That triggered a consumer backlash on social media sites.In reaction, late Friday Equifax reportedly said that the class-action waiver requirement in its terms of use for the Equifax site and TrustedID Premier, a related site, does not apply to this cybersecurity incident.More steps to protect yourself:Shares of Equifax (EFX), one of the three major U.S. credit bureaus, cratered on Friday, gapping down 14%. They plunged another 5% Monday to 166.61 to be 20% off their 52-week high.The sell-off followed both Equifax's Thursday disclosure of the data breach and its same-day disclosure that three senior executives sold shares worth almost $1.8 million in the days after the company realized on July 29 that it had been hacked. The company said the three executives had not been told of the breach when they sold shares on Aug. 1 and Aug. 2, Bloomberg reported.Some consumers expressed doubt that the executives sold shares without knowing about the breach. @rooroostar77 tweeted, "4 days before announcing the #EquifaxBreach execs sold nearly $2 million worth of shares. How are they not in jail?"Yet Equifax insisted the executive sells were just a coincidence. Bloomberg reported on Thursday, "The three 'sold a small percentage of their Equifax shares,' Ines Gutzmer, a spokeswoman for the Atlanta-based company, said in an emailed statement. They 'had no knowledge that an intrusion had occurred at the time.'"In addition, the hackers had accessed credit card numbers of about 209,000 consumers, Equifax revealed. Also, the thieves accessed what Equifax called some dispute documents containing personal identifying information for about 182,000 consumers.But the data breach occurred earlier, from mid-May through July 2017.RELATED:SEC Bulletin Might Bring Order To the Wild West ICO MarketHow Much Salary You Need To Buy A HomeWhat's The Stock Market Doing Now?

Credit score service Equifax (EFX) late Thursday announced a major cybersecurity breach exposed up to 143 million U.S. consumers. The breach occurred from mid-May to July 2017, Equifax said.The company said it found no evidence of unauthorized use of its core consumer or commercial credit reporting databases. The data hackers accessed names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and, in some instances, driver's license numbers. Credit card numbers for about 209,000 U.S. consumers, and certain dispute documents with personal identifying information for approximately 182,000 U.S. consumers, were also exposed."This is clearly a disappointing event for our company, and one that strikes at the heart of who we are and what we do. I apologize to consumers and our business customers for the concern and frustration this causes," Equifax CEO Richard Smith said in a statement.Equifax also identified unauthorized access to limited personal information for certain U.K. and Canadian residents.Equifax said it discovered the unauthorized access on July 29 and immediately acted to halt the intrusion.However, soon after the breach three top Equifax executives, including the CFO, sold a total of $1.8 million in shares, according to SEC filings that were not part of scheduled stock-sale programs, Bloomberg and others reported.The company said it will offer free credit monitoring for a year. It will mail notices to consumers with credit card numbers or dispute documents accessed.Equifax shares crashed 13% to 124.20 in late trading on the stock market today after tumbling much further.

As manager Joseph Fath closes in on his fourth anniversary at the helm of T. Rowe Price Growth Stock Fund (PRGFX) in January, the $50.7 billion portfolio continues to outperform. Its 28.73% gain this year going into Thursday outpaced 88% of its large-cap growth peers tracked by Morningstar Direct. Over the past three years it has notched a 14.54% annual gain, topping 92% of its direct rivals.XThe fund has managed its torrid pace by targeting leading stocks like e-commerce powerhouse Alibaba Group (BABA), graphics chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) and online payment processor PayPal Holdings (PYPL). Those stocks are up 94%, 81% and 80% so far this year. Alibaba and PayPal have been in the portfolio since the third quarter of 2016 and fourth quarter of 2015, respectively.Nvidia has been in and out of the portfolio in recent quarters.Fath and his growth stock team look for companies that have one or more of these traits: superior growth in earnings and cash flow; sustainable earnings momentum even in economic slowdowns; and a lucrative niche in the economy and ability to grow — even amid slow GDP growth.Take Alibaba. "Alibaba continues to benefit from improving user engagement amid its ongoing social commerce and mobile monetization efforts," Fath told shareholders in his semiannual report. "The massive amount of data that its users generate also provide the company with a competitive advantage that could drive long-term earnings growth."The Chinese Amazon's earnings-per-share growth has accelerated, having grown 30%, 37% and 60% the past three quarters. Annual EPS has grown for four years in a row. Consensus among analysts is that it will rise 44% this year.Alibaba is a longtime member of the Leaderboard — IBD's premium service that spotlights play-by-play moves of top stocks.Nvidia was been in and out of the portfolio in recent quarters as the fund initially took profits and then returned to the stock as we gained more conviction in the investment thesis, the growth stock team said.The stock's EPS growth is part of that process of persuasion. Its growth was at a triple-digit pace in four of the past five quarters. Still, operating costs have risen as the company invests in artificial intelligence and self-driving cars.The stock is ranked No. 1 in IBD's Electronics-Semiconductor Fabless industry group. That's due to achievements such as a 54% annual EPS growth rate over the past three years.IBD'S TAKE: You can see how Nvidia other fundamental and technical traits stack up against its rivals' in IBD's easy-to-understand Stock Checkup.PayPal EPS has also sped up, growing 9%, 13%, 17%, 19%, 28% and 31% in the past six quarters.The stock ranks No. 1 in IBD's Finance-Credit Card/Payment Processor industry group thanks to traits such as four straight years of annual EPS growth.The 31% September-quarter profit topped analysts' views. So did the 21% revenue increase. PayPal issued a current-quarter sales forecast that topped analyst estimates.PayPal is among the IBD 50 roster of fast-growing companies."We have a high conviction in PayPal as digital online payments are growing significantly on a global scale," Fath told shareholders. "The company's strong balance sheet and the potential to monetize its Venmo peer-to-peer payment platform could lead to further outperformance."Can Fath keep his streak going? That hinges partly on the performance of new stock buys, such as credit reporting bureau TransUnion (TRU), credit-card payment processor Vantiv (VNTV) and security software firm Symantec (SYMC).TransUnion shares got clobbered in the second week of September amid consumer anger and congressional inquiries sparked by the Equifax (EFX) data breach. But shares have rallied since then, resuming an uptrend that began late in 2016.While credit bureaus suffered withering criticism after the Equifax cyberattack, most of TransUnion's business comes from corporations. Only 23% of its revenue is from what the company calls its consumer interactive segment.And TransUnion has reinforced the corporate-focused part of its business with steps like its acquisition of Datalink Services, a leading provider of vehicle and driving records. The acquisition should enable TransUnion's DriverRisk to offer insurers a full-driving record platform.TransUnion, due to report third-quarter 2017 results before the opening bell on Oct. 27, was expected by analysts to post a 21% increase in earnings.Vantiv provides credit, debit and prepaid payment processing. It ranks No. 10 in PayPal's IBD industry group.Last summer the company beat rivals like PayPal to the punch by acquiring British-based Worldpay Group. The deal greatly expanded Vantiv's online capabilities.Third-quarter EPS, reported Thursday, rose 27% to 90 cents, up from Q2's 19% gain. Charles Drucker, president and CEO of Vantiv, said in a release, "We are investing in high growth segments of the market, including our combination with Worldpay, which will position us as a global acquirer with a leading position in e-commerce."Symantec develops internet and network security, storage and systems management applications for consumers and enterprises.Shares initially jumped on news of the Equifax breach. They've pulled back a little since early October, but have found support at their 50-day moving average.EPS grew an average of 21% in each of the past three quarters. Analysts estimate a 43% increase for the current stanza and 53% for the current fiscal year.RELATED:You Need This Much Retirement Savings At Your Age And IncomeTop Mutual Fund Manager Has Several Stocks In Buy Zone

Sonic (SONC), the drive-in burger chain known for its roller-skating carhops, is the latest target of hackers seeking consumers' credit-card accounts.The company suffered its worst stock decline in almost two months after disclosing a breach of its payment systems. The situation was brought to Sonic's attention last week by its credit-card processor, which flagged "unusual activity" with cards used at its restaurants."We are working to understand the nature and scope of this issue, as we know how important this is to our guests," the company said in a prepared statement. "We immediately engaged third-party forensic experts and law enforcement when we heard from our processor. While law enforcement limits the information we can share, we will communicate additional information as we are able."Brian Krebs, an independent journalist who investigates breaches, reported late Tuesday that the breach led to a "fire sale" on millions of stolen credit- and debit-card accounts. The information was put up for sale in a so-called theft bazaar called Joker's Stash, Krebs said.The shares fell as much as 4.4% to $23.52 on Wednesday, the biggest intraday drop since Aug. 8. The stock was down 7.2% this year through Tuesday's close, hurt by broader headwinds in the restaurant industry.The dangers of data breaches were thrown back in the spotlight this month after Equifax (EFX) exposed the data of 143 million Americans. The credit-reporting company said hackers accessed a vast trove of names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and driver's license numbers. Chief Executive Richard Smith stepped down in the wake of the revelations.Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) also disclosed a breach earlier this year, saying hackers had installed malicious software in order to grab customer data from point-of-sale devices.Sonic, based in Oklahoma City, serves about 3 million customers a day. Most of its 3,500 locations are operated by franchisees.

Pretty much everyone hates Equifax (EFX) right now. But despite the outrage over its handling of a data breach that left vulnerable the core identifying information for up to 143 million American customers, it won't exactly strangle profits for the credit reporting agency in the near term, a JPMorgan analyst says.XWhile emphasizing that it was still too early to gauge the full financial impact from the hack, JPMorgan analyst Andrew Steinerman cut his 2018 earnings-per-share outlook for Equifax by 10% —  to $6.16 from $6.83. For this year, Steinerman cut his 2017 EPS forecast to $5.87 from $6.08 — a 3% hit.He also cut his price target on the stock to 135 from 167. He has an overweight rating on the stock."Equifax is a well-capitalized company with strong free cash flow and an admirable innovative culture which should persist long after the effects of this data breach," he wrote in a research note on Thursday. "That said, the congressional hearings bear risk."Equifax CEO Richard Smith, who has apologized for the incident and vowed change, is set to testify before a House panel on Oct. 3. The Senate Finance Committee has also sought more information from the company related to the hack. The FTC also is investigating, the agency confirmed Thursday. Nearly 40 states have also joined an investigation of the matter, according to Reuters.Steinerman said new cybersecurity protocols, fines and an extended offering of the Equifax's TrustedID credit-monitoring service — which Equifax is currently giving out free for 12 months — could add to costs following those inquiries.The TrustedID offering seems likely to be the biggest cost for the company, Steinerman said. But exact numbers will depend on how many people actually use the service."Notably," he said, "the company is not automatically switching over paid customers to the free product, and we expect a 75% take rate for the free product amongst this paying population given a proven appreciation for credit monitoring offset by a natural level of nonswitching due to lack of awareness, laziness and other circumstances."Lawsuits and security costs could pile up, and there are questions about how much insurance will cover amid questions about Equifax's due diligence in keeping security tight, he said.Equifax fell 2.4% to 96.65 in the stock market today after tumbling intraday to 89.59, the worst since February 2015. The stock has plunged 32% since the breach was disclosed a week ago. TransUnion (TRU), another credit reporting company, lost 1.4%.IBD'S TAKE: For advice about how to protect yourself from being victimized by identity thieves, read this IBD report about how to take real-world, practical steps to safeguard yourself and your personal identification information.Rep. Carolyn Maloney, D-N.Y., on Wednesday requested information from the CEOs of TransUnion and Experian to learn more about how the companies are handling their own security in the wake of Equifax's troubles.Equifax has drawn criticism for disclosing the breach weeks after the company learned of it, and faced accusations that it hadn't done enough to protect itself following other cyber-intrusions.What's more, the company drew outrage after many people said the support services it set up in the wake of the data theft were insufficient and did not make it clear if their personal data was affected. Equifax, following widespread anger, has temporarily waived fees to freeze credit files, a precaution many have advised consumers to take following the breach.Three executives also sold Equifax shares a few days after the company discovered the breach, although the company has said the trio hadn't yet learned of the hack at the time. Senators have also sought more information on those sales as well.RELATED:Should You Join Lawsuits Mushrooming In Equifax Hack?What You Should Do Now To Protect Yourself From The Equifax Data BreachCybersecurity Stock Eyes Breakout After Equifax HackBanks And Financial Stocks: Latest News And Analysis

Fraudulent online account use has soared since July, says an e-commerce fraud-prevention executive, who adds that the increase in scam attempts is likely to be a result of the Equifax (EFX) data breach, which occurred from mid-May through July but was only disclosed by Equifax last week.XAnd in the wake of significant publicity about the data breach, LifeLock — which sells credit-monitoring services to consumers — says its web traffic soared sixfold and sign-ups increased 10-fold since Sept. 7, according to Bloomberg.Michael Reitblat, CEO and co-founder of e-commerce fraud-prevention company Forter, told IBD, "We've seen about a 15% increase in account takeover activity in the one and a half or two months since July. We can't be certain that it is from the Equifax hack. But the quality of data is higher, which leads us to think it is related. It is just circumstantial. But the (fraudsters) seem to have more authentic information."Reitblat says scam artists recently seem to have more than the usual amount of victims' actual identification information, such as Social Security numbers, names and addresses.Forter works by functioning as an intermediary when customers do online transactions. In real time, it aims to filter out attempts at using accounts created by crooks who obtained the accounts by using purloined information. The crooks create accounts that get billed to the people whose information was stolen. Forter reimburses retailers for transactions it authorizes that turn out to be by identity thieves."We review over $20 billion in transactions a year in the U.S.," Reitblat said.He adds that the Equifax data breach "looks like the essentially worst breach in U.S. history. It will have grave financial implications, not only for Equifax but for the whole financial ecosystem."Still, he anticipates a silver lining. "This will change the way merchants store data and share data. We will end up with a better, safer world" because merchants will implement systems that do a better job of screening out fraudulent transactions.Lifelock is part of software firm Symantec (SYMC).Equifax, one of the three major U.S. credit bureaus, says online thieves stole sensitive data for as many as 143 million U.S. consumers. The theft involved files that included people's names, Social Security numbers, birth dates, addresses and in some cases driver's license numbers.The hackers also accessed the credit-card numbers of about 209,000 consumers. And the thieves accessed what Equifax called some dispute documents containing personal identifying information for about 182,000 consumers.Equifax's stock has cratered 35% in the past two weeks.Symantec's stock broke out above a 33.32 buy point in an irregular base Tuesday before easing just below the buy point the past two days.  The stock ranks 4th in IBD's computer software security group, according to Stock Checkup.RELATED:Should You Join Lawsuits Mushrooming Against Equifax?What You Should Do Now To Protect Yourself From The Equifax Data BreachHow You Can Protect Yourself From The Equifax Identity-Theft HackWhat's The Stock Market Doing Now?

Equifax (EFX) shares slid to a seven-month low Friday after revealing late Thursday a data breach that impacted 143 million U.S. consumers — nearly 45% of the American population.XThe consumer credit reporting agency said between mid-May and July, hackers managed to access names, Social Security numbers, birth dates and certain driver's license numbers, as well as 209,000 U.S. consumers' credit card number and 182,000 U.S. consumers' dispute documents.Equifax said it discovered the hack on July 29, and has since started working with a "leading, independent cybersecurity firm" to assess the issue and conduct a "comprehensive forensic review."Shares sank 13.7% to 123.23 on the stock market today, diving below their 50- and 200-day averages as well as undoing the flat base it had been forming. Equifax fell as low as 117.25 intraday. TransUnion (TRU), another provider or credit information, dropped 3.8%.IBD'S TAKE: Equifax may be tumbling Friday, but a number of cybersecurity stocks are rising on news of the breach. At least one has surged into buy territory.Reports also said three Equifax executives sold $1.8 million in shares not long after the breach, though the company reportedly said those execs were not aware of the hack at the time of the sale.Equifax managers discovered the massive data breach, sold their stock worth $1.8 million, then told the public https://t.co/rL58Ar79lg— Mike Rosenberg (@ByRosenberg) September 7, 2017Long term, the company said it can still deliver 7%-10% revenue growth and 115-14% in adjusted per-share earnings on average, though the business will encounter "some disruption" in the near term. Management plans to update investors in October on the third-quarter earnings call.RELATED:Symantec, Proofpoint Shares Rise On Equifax Data BreachEquifax: Up To 143 Million Americans Affected By Huge Data BreachFireEye's Helix Platform Could Ignite Its Stock, Says AnalystStocks Mixed: Financials Snap Back, Video Game Makers Are 'Buys'

JPMorgan Chase (JPM) said Thursday that trading will likely be weak again in the fourth quarter, with no overt catalysts on the horizon, even as the effects of natural and man-made cataclysms loom.While the bank topped Q3 earnings forecasts, trading revenue dropped 16% to $5.5 billion, with fixed income revenue down 27% and equity market revenue down 4%.Brexit and Donald Trump's surprise election victory sparked a surge in volatility and trading last year, but activity has since quieted, weighing on banks' trading desks.A flurry of big events recently also won't appear to have much impact. Catalonia's attempt to separate from Spain was unlikely to "materially" affect business sentiment and global growth elsewhere could cushion against any minor difficulties, said CEO Jamie Dimon on a conference call with reporters.Hurricanes in the U.S. and Caribbean and earthquakes in Mexico had affected "many of our customers," the bank said in a statement, but management said during the call that their financial impact was "not significant."And as Wall Street waits for tax reform from Washington, D.C., CFO Marianne Lake indicated that JPMorgan wasn't emphasizing the subject in talks with some of its clients about loans."At this point, it's not front and center in the dialog we're having with our clients about whether they should or shouldn't do a strategic deal or take an action," she said on a conference call with analysts. "So I would say it's neither holding up business nor spurring business. But that could change."Shares slipped 0.9% to 95.99 in the stock market today, still within range of a 95.32 buy point of a flat base. Citigroup (C), which also beat views, fell 3.4% to 72.37 after briefly hitting its best intraday level since January 2009. Shares have now fallen back into buy range from a 69.96 entry, but the huge-volume slide should give investors pause.Among peers that report Friday, Bank of America (BAC) fell 1.5% to right at its 24.45 buy point, and Wells Fargo (WFC) eased 0.8% to 55.21, edging away from a double-bottom base buy point of 56.70.Goldman Sachs (GS) dipped 1.1% to 239.80, and Morgan Stanley (MS) lost 1.2% to 48.59. Both investment banking giants report next week.IBD'S TAKE: As an investor, you may wonder why buy points are important. The chart action of these top stocks offers an answer.JPMorgan's Q3 earnings per share of rose 11% to $1.76, topping Zacks Investment Research estimates for $1.67. Managed revenue grew 3% to $26.2 billion, while reported revenue of $25.33 billion fell short of Zacks views for $25.68 billion. Average core loans rose 7%, slowing from the previous quarter. Investment banking revenue fell 2%.In contrast with weak trading results, the retail side was stronger. Lending revenue rose 17%, and consumer and business banking revenue grew 15%.The bank had a reserve build of $300 million for its credit-card business, although it said the credit environment remained "benign" and that demand for credit remained solid. The reserves are used to cushion against bad loans."While higher reserve build in Card may give some investors pause, underlying revenue/expense trends were strong," Nomura-Instinet analyst Steven Chubak said in a research note.JPMorgan said that credit-card spending had moderated but remained strong and that engagement for its premium Chase Sapphire Reserve card was also good.But as banking becomes more smartphone-based — JPMorgan active mobile customers jumped 12% in the third quarter — Lake said later in the day that "branches still matter," adding that 75% of the bank's growth in deposits came from customers using branches.Still, she said the bank was keeping pace with customers' changing preferences, and that net for the year, the bank would have 125 fewer branch locations.JPMorgan also said it hadn't seen any specific uptick in fraud following the massive data breach at Equifax (EFX).Meanwhile, Citigroup's EPS climbed 14% to $1.42, better than estimates for $1.32, as revenue rose 2% to $18.17 billion, beating forecasts for $17.85 billion.Fixed-income revenue fell 11% to $2.88 billion, while equity markets revenue rose 10% to $757 million. Consumer banking revenue grew 3% to $8.4 billion, and institutional clients revenue climbed 9% to $9.2 billion. Citi built up another roughly $500 million in reserves for its North American card business.RELATED: Big Bank Earnings This Week: What To WatchBank Of America, JPMorgan Lead 5 Banks Hitting Buys As GOP Tax Plan Boosts YieldsBuffett Says He'll Hold This Bank Stock For A 'Long, Long, Long' TimeCould Goldman Sachs Be The First Bank To Offer Bitcoin Trades?
